title: Authors and Citation
text: Josh Weinstock. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Weinstock J (2025). gwasplot: High Performance GWAS Plotting Annotation. R package version 0.1.0, https://github.com/weinstockj/gwasplot.
code: @Manual{,   title = {gwasplot: High Performance GWAS Plotting And Annotation},   author = {Josh Weinstock},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.1.0},   url = {https://github.com/weinstockj/gwasplot}, }

what: High Performance GWAS Plotting And Annotation
title: High Performance GWAS Plotting And Annotation
text: gwasplot provides fast efficient tools visualizing annotating GWAS summary statistics. offers functions reformat data, create plots, annotate top hits genomic features. designed work output GWAS performed WGS data many rare variants, using duckdb manipulate data. information, visit GitHub repository project website.

title: High Performance GWAS Plotting And Annotation
text: Install development version gwasplot GitHub:
code: # Install remotes if not already installed if (!requireNamespace("remotes", quietly = TRUE)) {   install.packages("remotes") }  # Install gwasplot from GitHub remotes::install_github("weinstockj/gwasplot")

title: High Performance GWAS Plotting And Annotation
text: gwasplot expects output either regenie saige csv parquet format (parquet generally recommended). Regenie output looks like : gwastools read data either regenie saige standarize column names, create table called summary_stats duckdb database.

title: High Performance GWAS Plotting And Annotation
text: gwasplot includes robust filtering capabilities remove variants problematic genomic regions can lead spurious associations:

title: High Performance GWAS Plotting And Annotation
text: exclude_difficult_regions() function removes variants regions known mapping difficulties: Available region types include: - hg19diff: Regions assembly differences genome builds - UCSC_unusual: Unusual regions identified UCSC (gaps, heterochromatin, etc.) - GRC_exclusions: Genome Reference Consortium exclusion regions - GIAB_difficult_regions: Genome Bottle difficult--map regions
code: # Remove variants from multiple types of difficult regions gwas_filtered <- exclude_difficult_regions(gwas_stats,                                           beds_exclude = c("hg19diff", "UCSC_unusual", "GRC_exclusions"))

title: High Performance GWAS Plotting And Annotation
text: Filter variants using custom whitelists blacklists:
code: # Keep only variants in a specific region or set filtered_gwas <- filter_variants(gwas_stats, subset = "my_variants.parquet")  # Exclude specific variants filtered_gwas <- filter_variants(gwas_stats, exclude = "bad_variants.parquet")

title: High Performance GWAS Plotting And Annotation
text: Annotate variants nearest protein-coding genes: Additional specialized annotations: - CHIP genes: annotate_with_chip_genes() - flags variants clonal hematopoiesis genes - Centromeres: annotate_with_centromere() - identifies variants centromeric regions - Immunoglobulin loci: annotate_with_immunoglobulin() - flags variants Ig heavy/light chain regions
code: # Add gene annotations annotated_gwas <- find_nearest_gene(gwas_stats, threshold = 1e5)  # 100kb window

title: High Performance GWAS Plotting And Annotation
High Performance GWAS Plotting And Annotation
High Performance GWAS Plotting And Annotation
text: Create detailed regional association plots gene tracks:
code: # Plot a specific locus with gene structure locuszoom(gwas_stats, locus_chr = "chr2", locus_start = 25000000, locus_end = 25500000)

title: High Performance GWAS Plotting And Annotation
text: post-GWAS analysis (e.g., empirical Bayes shrinkage):
code: # Automatically uses lfsr if available, otherwise p-values volcano(gwas_data, phenotype_label = "My Phenotype")

title: High Performance GWAS Plotting And Annotation
text: sample usage examples:

title: High Performance GWAS Plotting And Annotation
text: Reformat GWAS Summary Statistics Use reformat_summary_statistics function read reformat GWAS summary statistics parquet CSV file:
code: library(gwasplot)  # Reformat summary statistics from a file gwas_stats <- reformat_summary_statistics("path/to/your/file.parquet") print(gwas_stats)  GWAS object File path: ../concatenated_results.parquet Detected format: regenie Data names: CHROM, POS, ID, ALLELE0, ALLELE1, A1FREQ, N, BETA, SE, CHISQ, LOG10P, phenotype Data preview: # A tibble: 5 × 9   CHROM      POS REF   ALT      AF_ALT     BETA  LOG10P PVALUE ID   <chr>    <dbl> <chr> <chr>     <dbl>    <dbl>   <dbl>  <dbl> <chr> 1 chr3  90000011 T     C     0.000138  -0.00157 0.00753  0.983 chr3_90000011_T_C 2 chr3  90000261 GATT  G     0.000291  -0.0646  0.751    0.178 chr3_90000261_GA… 3 chr3  90000274 T     A     0.000238  -0.0645  0.634    0.232 chr3_90000274_T_A 4 chr3  90000324 C     A     0.000163   0.0280  0.177    0.665 chr3_90000324_C_A 5 chr3  90000366 T     G     0.0000466 -0.0211  0.0644   0.862 chr3_90000366_T_G

title: High Performance GWAS Plotting And Annotation
code: # Load and reformat data gwas_stats <- reformat_summary_statistics("path/to/gwas_results.parquet")  # Quality control: remove problematic regions for WGS GWAS gwas_clean <- gwas_stats %>%   exclude_difficult_regions(     beds_exclude = c(       "hg19diff",        "UCSC_unusual",        "GRC_exclusions"       )     )   manhattan(gwas_clean, output_prefix = "my_analysis") qqplot(gwas_clean, output_prefix = "my_analysis")  # Get top hits and annotate with genes top_hits <- gwas_clean %>%   select_top_hits(threshold = 5e-8) %>%   find_nearest_gene()  # Plot specific loci locuszoom(gwas_clean, locus_chr = "chr2", locus_start = 25000000, locus_end = 25500000)

title: High Performance GWAS Plotting And Annotation
text: Email Josh Weinstock. See work .

what: Annotate data with centromere information — annotate_with_centromere
title: Annotate data with centromere information — annotate_with_centromere
text: Annotate data centromere information

title: Annotate data with centromere information — annotate_with_centromere
code: annotate_with_centromere(x, ...)  # S3 method for class 'data.frame' annotate_with_centromere(x, chrom_col = "CHROM", pos_col = "POS", ...)  # S3 method for class 'tbl_df' annotate_with_centromere(x, ...)  # S3 method for class 'GWASFormatter' annotate_with_centromere(x, ...)

title: Annotate data with centromere information — annotate_with_centromere
text: x data frame tibble containing variant data. ... Additional arguments passed methods. chrom_col Name column containing chromosome information. Default "CHROM". pos_col Name column containing position information. Default "POS".

what: Find the nearest gene for variants — find_nearest_gene
title: Find the nearest gene for variants — find_nearest_gene
text: Find nearest gene variants

title: Find the nearest gene for variants — find_nearest_gene
code: find_nearest_gene(x, ...)  # S3 method for class 'GWASFormatter' find_nearest_gene(x, threshold = 1e+05, ...)  # S3 method for class 'tbl_df' find_nearest_gene(   x,   threshold = 1e+05,   chrom_col = "CHROM",   pos_col = "POS",   id_col = "ID",   ... )

title: Find the nearest gene for variants — find_nearest_gene
text: x gwas object tibble containing variant data. ... Additional arguments passed methods. threshold distance threshold consider gene nearest. Default 1e5. chrom_col Name column containing chromosome information. Default "CHROM". pos_col Name column containing position information. Default "POS". id_col Name column containing variant IDs. Default "ID".

title: LocusZoom-style plot for GWAS results — locuszoom
text: x GWASFormatter object data.frame/tibble containing GWAS results. locus_chr Chromosome locus plot (e.g., 'chr1'). locus_start Start position locus (integer). locus_end End position locus (integer). include_ccres Logical, whether include ENCODE SCREEN cCREs track. Default FALSE. ccre_biosample Optional biosample ID biosample-specific cCRE filtering (e.g., "GM12878_ENCDO000AAK"). ccre_cell_type Optional cell type name cCRE filtering (e.g., "GM12878"). converted biosample ID. ... Additional arguments passed methods.

title: QQ plot for p-values — qqplot
code: qqplot(   pvalues,   should.thin = TRUE,   thin.obs.places = 2,   thin.exp.places = 2,   xlab = expression(paste("Expected (", -log[10], " p-value)")),   ylab = expression(paste("Observed (", -log[10], " p-value)")),   draw.conf = TRUE,   conf.points = 1000,   conf.col = "lightgray",   conf.alpha = 0.05,   already.transformed = FALSE,   point.size = 1.5,   point.alpha = 0.7,   point.color = "#3366FF",   ... )

title: QQ plot for p-values — qqplot
text: pvalues numeric vector p-values list numeric vectors p-values. .thin Logical indicating whether thin points plotting. Default TRUE. thin.obs.places Number decimal places round observed p-values thinning. Default 2. thin.exp.places Number decimal places round expected p-values thinning. Default 2.
